entry.title: What is "expected" vs what is "required"
entry.summary: I was cleaning out my phone the other day and found a pitch-black video from June 2022 where I recorded some thoughts I had completely forgotten about: When use the word "expectations," we're rarely actually talking about what's "expected." It's standard to call all of…
entry.content:
I was cleaning out my phone the other day and found a pitch-black video from June 2022 where I recorded some thoughts I had completely forgotten about:

When use the word "expectations," we're rarely actually talking about what's "expected."

  • No teacher truly anticipates that they are going to go a full school year without anyone failing, missing an assignment, or talking out of turn.
  • No boss is going to predict that all of their employees are going to come in on time 100% of the time, meet every quota, and memorize every policy perfectly.
  • No one is shocked when they drive out onto the road and encounter other drivers who speed, tailgate, act obliviously, or look at their phone on the highway.

It's standard to call all of those things "expectations," but they're not things we genuinely expect from others - or at least not 100% of the time.

What we're really talking about here are standards, norms, and requirements.

A teacher requires you to act a certain way, but they never expect total compliance. Same goes for your boss. And when someone doesn't comply - there are consequences.

One thought led to another and I asked myself:

What are God's expectations?

He sets a high standard. Don't even look at someone with hatred in your heart. Or lust. Forgive everyone every time. Treat even your enemy as you want to be treated. Be willing to die for those you love (which should mean everyone.) These are what we might call his "expectations." But what does he actuallyÂ expect?

He anticipates that we've already sinned. He knows that we continue to sin. And he predicts that in our imperfection, we will unfortunately keep on sinning.

Even so: 1 John 2:1Â 

"My little children, I am writing these things to you so that you may not sin. But if anyone does sin, we have an advocate with the Father, Jesus Christ the righteous."

There are four obvious takeaways:

  1. He does not want us to keep sinning
  2. God and his people actively work to minimize sin
  3. He isn't surprised by the fact that we keep sinning anyway
  4. He prepared for it and made a plan to deal with it

So note to self:

Stop punishing yourself for being imperfect

Let's say Jeff invites Andrew on a hike, but Jeff knows Andrew is in a wheelchair. Andrew says no at first, knowing he would progress a lot slower and couldn't go to all the same places that Jeff can. He's just not capable. But Jeff is persistent. He asks and asks Andrew to join him until he finally gives in.

So should Andrew beat himself up for slowing Jeff down? Should Andrew be upset when he has to really on Jeff to carry him and his wheelchair through unpaved sections of the trail? Of course not!Â Jeff invited him, knowing the cost.Â 

Jesus has invited in despite knowing the cost to himself. He wanted it that badly, and he'll carry us through those places we find ourselves incapable of carrying ourselves. That's what he died for.

entry.title: The Hensel Twins ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ¤â€ğŸ§‘
entry.summary: Abby & Brittany Hensel are dicephalic parapagus twins (having two heads joined to one torso.) Since 2013, the two have worked as teachers. Each has a heart, stomach, spine, pair of lungs, and spinal cord. Each twin controls one arm and one leg. When they…
entry.content:
Abby & Brittany Hensel are dicephalic parapagus twins (having two heads joined to one torso.) Since 2013, the two have worked as teachers.

Each has a heart, stomach, spine, pair of lungs, and spinal cord. Each twin controls one arm and one leg. When they were infants, learning to crawl, walk, and clap required cooperation. They can eat and write separately and simultaneously. Activities such as running, swimming, hair-brushing, playing piano or volleyball, riding a bicycle, or driving a car require coordination.

The twins' lives have been covered in the popular media, including Life magazine and The Oprah Winfrey Show. They were interviewed on The Learning Channel in December 2006, discussing their daily lives and future plans. They starred in their own reality television series, Abby & Brittany, on TLC in 2012.[1][2]

entry.title: Blue Lobster ğŸ¦
entry.summary: Mutations â†’ âˆŸOrganisms â†’ Lobster âˆŸTypes â†’ Discoloration â†’ Blue Not to be confused with the Procambarus alleni (â€œblue lobsterâ€ crayfish) or the arguably even cooler Homarus, these are mutated varieties of the American Lobster that were born blue instead of its usual brownish coloration.
entry.content:
Mutations â†’Â 
âˆŸOrganisms â†’ Lobster
âˆŸTypes â†’ Discoloration â†’ Blue

Not to be confused with the Procambarus alleni (â€œblue lobsterâ€ crayfish) or the arguably even cooler Homarus, these are mutated varieties of the American Lobster that were born blue instead of its usual brownish coloration.

Such lobstersâ€™s reported rarity can fall anywhere from 1/1,000,000 to 1 in 10,000,000 (depending on your source).Â An excessive production of proteins combined with astaxanthin create the unusual blue color. However, it seems equally likely to me that their parents were simply fed an incredible number of blueberries â€“ thus creating a blueberry flavored lobster.

VariationsÂ 

Still othersâ€™ blue color is split right down the middle.

Other shiny Pokemon variants include: 1/2 Split Lobsters, Albino Lobsters, Orange Lobsters, and Yellow Lobsters

Cause of discoloration

Per an article on Shrimpnews.com, their Blue color can more accurately be attributed as such:

Once inside the lobster, things get more complicated. The shell of the lobster has three layers, and the pigment (called astaxanthin) is found in all of them. In the innermost layer, the epidermis, the pigment is incorporated without any changes, showing off the original bright red. As it travels further to outer layer, it forms even larger clusters that look yellow.
In a living lobster, these beautiful bright colors appear all mixed together, creating a dingy brown. There may be hints of blue around the tail, but nothing that reveals the intricate colors underneath. There are exceptions. In one in every million or so lobsters, the layering doesnâ€™t work as it should. If both the top and bottom layers of the shell fail to incorporate the pigment, you get a regal, bright blue lobster

Â

entry.title: Tortoiseshell Gynandromorph ğŸˆ
entry.summary: Mutations â†’ âˆŸOrganisms â†’ Cat âˆŸTypes â†’ Two-in-One â†’ Gynandromorph In cats, Tortoiseshell coats are associated with the X chromosome, thus they normally only appear in females. Male Tortoiseshells, however, are not unheard of. This can be caused by chimerism or mosaicism - where the…
entry.content:
Mutations â†’Â 
âˆŸOrganisms â†’ Cat
âˆŸTypes â†’ Two-in-One â†’ Gynandromorph

In cats, Tortoiseshell coats are associated with the X chromosome, thus they normally only appear in females.

Male Tortoiseshells, however, are not unheard of. This can be caused by chimerism or mosaicism - where the cat is born with cells containing both male and female genetics. This can also be caused by Klinefelter syndrome, where the cat is born with XXY chromosomes.

Calico cats are identical to tortoiseshell in every way except that their undercoat is white, wherease tortoiseshells' undercoats are black. Thus there have also been Calico Gynanders

Tortoiseshells are considered good luck in Ireland and Japan.

Â

entry.title: Calico Gynandromorph ğŸˆ
entry.summary: Mutations â†’ âˆŸOrganisms â†’ Cat âˆŸTypes â†’ Two-in-One â†’ Gynandromorph In cats, calico coats are associated with the X chromosome, thus they normally only appear in females. Male calicos, however, are not unheard of. This can be caused by chimerism or mosaicism - where the…
entry.content:
Mutations â†’Â 
âˆŸOrganisms â†’ Cat
âˆŸTypes â†’ Two-in-One â†’ Gynandromorph

In cats, calico coats are associated with the X chromosome, thus they normally only appear in females.

Male calicos, however, are not unheard of. This can be caused by chimerism or mosaicism - where the cat is born with cells containing both male and female genetics.

This can also be caused by Klinefelter syndrome, where the cat is born with XXY chromosomes.

Calico cats are identical to tortoiseshell in every way except that their undercoat is white, wherease tortoiseshells' undercoats are black. Thus there have also been Tortoiseshell Gynanders.

In German and Japanese folklore, calico's are considered to be good luck.

This of course comes in contrast to black cats, which are often imagined to be bad luck.

Â
